verses.text: After we tore ourselves away from them and set sail, we went straight to Cos, then the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verses.comment: Paul’s departure is marked by deep emotion, showing the close bonds among believers. The travel itinerary underscores Luke’s attention to eyewitness detail.

verses.text: There we found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, so we boarded and set sail.
verses.comment: Here begins Paul's journey towards Jerusalem, prefiguring Jesus’ own determination to go up to Jerusalem (Luke 9:51).

verses.text: When we had come in sight of Cyprus, leaving it on our left, we sailed to Syria and landed at Tyre, for there the ship was to unload its cargo.
verses.comment: Tyre is significant in prophetic history and was a place where believers were now present. Paul’s route follows the ancient paths of prophets and apostles.

verses.text: And having found the disciples there, we stayed seven days. Through the Spirit, they urged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The Spirit’s warning mirrors prior prophecies, yet Paul’s obedience to God’s will takes precedence. Seven days hints at completion and the apostolic rhythm of worship—a subtle reflection of continuity in the faith community.

verses.text: When our time was up, we left and continued our journey. All the disciples, with wives and children, accompanied us out of the city. We knelt down on the beach and prayed.
verses.comment: The image of entire families praying together reflects the holistic spiritual unity of the early church, echoing Old Testament precedents of family worship (Ps. 78:4).

verses.text: After saying farewell to each other, we boarded the ship, and they returned home.
verses.comment: The tenderness of the farewell continues to reinforce the importance of close fellowship in the Church.

verses.text: We sailed from Tyre and arrived at Ptolemais. When we greeted the brothers, we stayed with them for one day.
verses.comment: Ptolemais was a significant early Christian community. Greeting the brethren shows the universal fellowship binding believers together.

verses.text: The next day we departed and went to Caesarea. There we entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the Seven, and stayed with him.
verses.comment: Philip’s continued ministry demonstrates apostolic succession and faithful service. His hospitality models Christian charity.

verses.text: He had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.
verses.comment: This fulfillment of Joel’s prophecy highlights the Spirit’s ongoing work in the Church through both men and women. Spiritual gifts are richly distributed.

verses.text: While we were staying there for many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
verses.comment: Agabus represents the continuation of prophetic ministry after Christ’s ascension, showing the Spirit’s governance over the Church.

verses.text: He came to us, took Paul’s belt, bound his own feet and hands, and said, 'Thus says the Holy Spirit: In this way the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: Dramatic prophecy echoes the Old Testament prophets’ symbolic actions (cf. Jeremiah). Paul’s coming suffering parallels Christ’s own Passion, indicating the cost of discipleship.

verses.text: When we heard these things, both we and the people there pleaded with Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The concern for Paul’s safety emphasizes the deep pastoral care in the Church, reflecting Christ’s own sacrificial warning to his disciples (Matt. 16:21).

verses.text: Then Paul answered, 'Why are you weeping and breaking my heart? I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.'
verses.comment: Paul’s declaration mirrors the apostolic commitment, setting an example of total devotion reminiscent of Christ, who went willingly to Jerusalem to suffer.

verses.text: When he would not be persuaded, we ceased and said, 'Let the Lord’s will be done.'
verses.comment: The submission to God’s will echoes Jesus' prayer at Gethsemane, emphasizing obedience to divine Providence.

verses.text: After those days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The phrase 'went up' underlines the spiritual significance of Jerusalem as the center of worship and missionary activity.

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea came with us, bringing us to Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we would stay.
verses.comment: Hospitality among believers reflects Christ’s command to love one another and the early Church’s unity.

verses.text: When we reached Jerusalem, the brothers welcomed us gladly.
verses.comment: The Jerusalem church receives missionaries with joy, reflecting Christian unity and mutual encouragement.

verses.text: The next day, Paul went with us to James, and all the elders were present.
verses.comment: Paul approaches the leader of the Jerusalem church and its elders, reflecting the importance of apostolic leadership and the visible, organized authority in the Church.

verses.text: After greeting them, Paul told in detail what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verses.comment: Paul gives an account to the Church’s leaders, reflecting the pattern of mission and accountability present from the start.

verses.text: When they heard it, they glorified God. Then they said to him, 'You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who have believed, and they are all zealous for the law.'
verses.comment: Jewish believers’ zeal for the law demonstrates the ongoing importance of sacrificial worship, yet Paul’s mission shows fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: 'They have been informed about you—that you teach all Jews among the Gentiles to abandon Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or walk according to our customs.'
verses.comment: The accusation against Paul reflects misunderstanding; Paul preaches Christ as fulfillment of the law, not its abolition (Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: 'What then should we do? They will surely hear that you have come.'
verses.comment: The elders recognize the challenge—unity and truth must be preserved amidst controversy within the Church.

verses.text: 'So do what we tell you: We have four men who have taken a vow.'
verses.comment: The vow referenced is likely the Nazirite vow, a sign of sanctification. The elders advise Paul to cooperate with established religious practice to foster peace.

verses.text: 'Take these men and purify yourself along with them; pay their expenses so that they may shave their heads. That way all will know there’s nothing to the rumors they have heard about you, but that you yourself also live in observance of the law.'
verses.comment: Paul’s participation affirms his respect for ancient rites, supporting the Church’s mission to unite both Jewish and Gentile believers in Christ.

verses.text: 'As for the Gentile believers, we wrote to them, having decided that they should abstain from things offered to idols, from blood, from what is strangled, and from sexual immorality.'
verses.comment: Reference to the Jerusalem council’s decision highlights the Church’s authority to bind and loose practices, a sign of its spiritual governance.

verses.text: Then Paul took the men, and the next day, purifying himself along with them, he entered the temple, giving notice of the completion of the days of purification until the offering was made for each one of them.
verses.comment: Paul’s temple worship underscores the continuity of worship practices until the fulfillment in Christ. The offering reflects the unity of sacrifice and community.

verses.text: When the seven days were nearly over, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the entire crowd and laid hands on him.
verses.comment: Hostility to Paul prefigures Christ’s own rejection in Jerusalem; persecution and suffering are marks of the mission.

verses.text: They cried out, 'Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people, the law, and this place. Furthermore, he has brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.'
verses.comment: Paul is accused of blasphemy and desecration; the charge is false but reflects the recurrent tension over the universality of Christ’s salvation.

verses.text: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.
verses.comment: Mistaken assumptions and suspicion arise; Paul’s Gentile companion stirs controversy, showing early Church debates about inclusion.

verses.text: The whole city was stirred up, and the people ran together. They seized Paul, dragged him out of the temple, and immediately its gates were shut.
verses.comment: The shutting of the gates signifies exclusion and impending judgment. The mob’s reaction mirrors the treatment of the prophets.

verses.text: While they were trying to kill him, news reached the commander of the Roman cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.
verses.comment: Roman authority intervenes, reminding us of the intersection of faith and temporal power, much as it did in Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: He immediately took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them; when they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.comment: Roman soldiers provide order in chaos, preparing the setting for Paul’s public witness.

verses.text: Then the commander came up, arrested Paul, ordered him to be bound with two chains, and asked who he was and what he had done.
verses.comment: Paul experiences literal binding, fulfilling Agabus’ prophecy. Arrest and questioning begin Paul’s defense of the faith before the powers.

verses.text: Some in the crowd shouted one thing, some another; when he could not determine the facts because of the uproar, he ordered Paul to be brought into the barracks.
verses.comment: Confusion and division in the crowd contrasts with the order of the Church; Paul suffers amid chaos, just as Christ did.

verses.text: When Paul reached the steps, the soldiers had to carry him because of the violence of the crowd.
verses.comment: The image echoes Psalm passages about being lifted up amidst persecution (Ps. 27:2). Paul’s suffering is joined to Christ’s.

verses.text: For the mob followed, shouting, 'Away with him!'
verses.comment: Their cry recalls the rejection of Jesus, drawing a direct parallel between Paul’s experience and Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the commander, 'May I speak to you?' He replied, 'Do you know Greek?'
verses.comment: Paul’s use of Greek, the language of the educated world, displays the universality of his mission; he is prepared to testify before all nations.

verses.text: 'Aren’t you the Egyptian who recently incited a revolt and led four thousand terrorists into the wilderness?'
verses.comment: The commander’s confusion highlights the misunderstandings and false accusations that often accompany missionary work.

verses.text: Paul answered, 'I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city. Please, let me speak to the people.'
verses.comment: Paul appeals to his heritage and citizenship, emulating Christ’s strategy of speaking to both Jewish and Gentile audiences.

verses.text: After the commander allowed him, Paul stood on the steps and motioned to the people. When there was a great silence, he addressed them in the Hebrew language:
verses.comment: Paul’s address in Hebrew shows his deep respect for Jewish tradition, and the importance of communicating the Gospel in its fullness and with reverence for sacred history.
